user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_alloc:
```c
static int lfs_alloc(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_block_t *block) {
    while (true) {
        // scan our lookahead buffer for free blocks
        while (lfs->lookahead.next < lfs->lookahead.size) {
            if (!(lfs->lookahead.buffer[lfs->lookahead.next / 8]
                    & (1U << (lfs->lookahead.next % 8)))) {
                // found a free block
                *block = (lfs->lookahead.start + lfs->lookahead.next)
                        % lfs->block_count;

                // eagerly find next free block to maximize how many blocks
                // lfs_alloc_ckpoint makes available for scanning
                while (true) {
                    lfs->lookahead.next += 1;
                    lfs->lookahead.ckpoint -= 1;

                    if (lfs->lookahead.next >= lfs->lookahead.size
                            || !(lfs->lookahead.buffer[lfs->lookahead.next / 8]
                                & (1U << (lfs->lookahead.next % 8)))) {
                        return 0;
                    }
                }
            }

            lfs->lookahead.next += 1;
            lfs->lookahead.ckpoint -= 1;
        }

        // In order to keep our block allocator from spinning forever when our
        // filesystem is full, we mark points where there are no in-flight
        // allocations with a checkpoint before starting a set of allocations.
        //
        // If we've looked at all blocks since the last checkpoint, we report
        // the filesystem as out of storage.
        //
        if (lfs->lookahead.ckpoint <= 0) {
            LFS_ERROR("No more free space 0x%"PRIx32,
                    (lfs->lookahead.start + lfs->lookahead.next)
                        % lfs->block_count);
            return LFS_ERR_NOSPC;
        }

        // No blocks in our lookahead buffer, we need to scan the filesystem for
        // unused blocks in the next lookahead window.
        int err = lfs_alloc_scan(lfs);
        if(err) {
            return err;
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragment modifies the pointer parameters themselves. The function assigns to *block (writing the object pointed to) and modifies members of the object pointed to by lfs (e.g., lfs->lookahead.next, lfs->lookahead.ckpoint). These are permitted by Rule 17.8 (the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified). There are no statements reassigning the pointer variables (no occurrences of lfs = ..., block = ..., block += ..., block++ or similar), so there are no fragments that violate the rule and none need further investigation under Rule 17.8.
